alert.note: Alert for Hampden; Hampshire (Massachusetts) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 6:09PM EDT until July 14 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed to Minor severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Massachusetts... Connecticut River Below Holyoke affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River Above Holyoke Dam affecting Hampden County. ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Massachusetts... Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampshire and Hampden Counties. Connecticut River At Montague affecting Hampshire and Franklin Counties. For the Connecticut River...including Montague, Northampton, Holyoke Dam, Holyoke, Springfield, Thompsonville, Hartford, Middle Haddam... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Connecticut River at Northampton. * WHEN...Until Friday morning. * IMPACTS...At 115.0 feet, Flooding affects a large portion of the Oxbow in Northampton. Flood waters also reach Route 5, a portion of which may be impassable. Flooding spreads across the lower lying sections of Hadley. In Hatfield, back water from the Connecticut River will push the Mill River over its banks, flooding parts of Valley Street and surrounding areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:00 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 115.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 112.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 5:00 PM EDT Tuesday was 115.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 115.3 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday morning. - Flood stage is 112.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 115.3 feet on 04/24/1958. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Wednesday morning at 615 AM EDT.
